patches.reasoning: Added prior knowledge to ensure pupils have the foundational understanding needed before beginning the lesson on the end of Roman Britain.

value: The Romans invaded Britain in AD 43.
Roman Britain was part of the Roman Empire for nearly 400 years.
The Romans built roads and towns in Britain.
Roman soldiers lived in forts throughout Britain.

patches.reasoning: Key learning points are added to focus on the essential knowledge pupils should acquire during the lesson.

value: The Romans left Britain around AD 410 due to pressures elsewhere in the Roman Empire.
After the Romans left, Britain was more vulnerable to invasions by groups such as the Saxons.
The Roman departure led to changes in Britain's infrastructure and society, such as the decline of Roman towns.
Different groups in Britain adapted in various ways after the Romans left, leading to new cultures and societies.

patches.reasoning: Identified misconceptions to address common errors or misunderstandings pupils might have about the topic.

value.misconception: The Romans were forced to leave Britain by the Saxons
value.description: Explain that the Romans left due to pressures in other parts of their empire, not directly because of the Saxons.

value.misconception: Roman roads and towns disappeared immediately after they left
value.description: Clarify that while some Roman infrastructure declined, much of it remained and influenced later developments.

value.misconception: All Britons were sad to see the Romans leave
value.description: Discuss how some groups may have seen the Roman departure as an opportunity to gain power or independence.

value.definition: A group of countries or regions that are controlled by one ruler or one government.
The act of entering a place by force, in order to take control of it.
The basic physical systems of a country, such as roads and bridges.
A member of a Germanic people who invaded and settled in Britain in the early Middle Ages.
